no JUSTICES OF TIE PEACE.

The London Monthly Magazine gives the follow
ing method by which the Portuguese preserve cab
bage on board their ships. The cabbage is cut SO
as to leave about two inches or of the stem at
tached toit; after which the ph is scooped out to
to about the depth Of in-h, peing taken not
wound or bruise the rnd by this operation. The
cabbages then are suspended by means of a cord,
tied round that portion OF the stem next the cabbage,
and fastened at regular intervals to rope across
the decks. That portion of the stem from which
the pith is taken being uppermost, is regularly fill
ed with water during very long voyages. The same
method might be advantageously adopted in private
houses.
PRESERVATION OF CABBAGEs.

By JAMES EpmEsroS, LuNpJN
Where Can go from INes.i
All present Deity!
nature, and 'ilne and Thought, thine impress bear
through earth, or sea, sky,
Though far afal IL f1y,
iturn' and Ind Thee present with me there,
The perfume Of the rose,


And every Hover that blows,
All mark thy love, in clusters of the vale;
The corn that crowns the fields,
The fruits the garden yields,
FrociaIn the bounties that can never fail
The vapour and the cloud,


The Thunder bursting loud.
speak or Thy majesty in words of flame;
The ocean as it loary


Lasling the rocks and shores,
declares from what mighty hand it came.
The vastly globes that roll


Each on its own firm pole,
Through all the boundless fields of space alone,
froVe that indeed Thou art,
The ite-wheel and the heart,
vi systems to our little world unknown
From Thee Icannot fly;


THINE all observing eye,


Marks the ,nnutest atom of Thy reign;
How far so'er 30,


lhou all my path woudst know,
And bring the wandererto this earth again.
But why should depart?


Ills safety where Thou art :
And could one spot Thy being hold,
l, poor, and vain, and weak,


That sacred spot would seek,
And dwell within The shelter OF Thy fold !

From the London Eclectic Revieuy.

SIR:-Gve this a place in your Farmer. .sAs
soon as trees are taken up, dip their roots in pud-
die of COW dung and loan, which preserves their
hbres from the influence of the air.


When this practice is adopted in the winter seas
on, the plants may be sent to any distance or kept
out of the ground iorweeks, without the slightest in
jury.


You may transplant trees in the heat of summer
by this precaution, and with perfect success. Sin
cerely yours, L. w.
J. S. Skinner, Esq.
TRANSPLANTING TREES.

South-Carolina, August &c, 1897.
Mr.. SKINNER,


SIR Having seen in your paper, No l5, some
remarks by farmer OF Frederick county, Va. reia-
tive to cheat in wheat; and giving his opinion thai
wheat does not turn to cheat, have thought proper
to offer you an experimental fact, and if you think
It merits place in your useful paper, you can give
It one. In the year 1928. my crop of wheat had in
it considerable quantity of cheat which was at
loss to account for. had seen none the preceding
year; but in order to clear my wheat from cheat
entirely, as thought, selected from the best part
Of my crop some of the best bundles, and carefully
separated all the cheat from The wheat before it was
threshed this work was not entrusted to servants,
or 10 any other person but tmysef; was, therefore,
perfectly satisfied that no cheat was left with the
wheat; this wheat was seeded separate from any
other; but when it became of such size as to dis
tnguish it from the cheat and from that time until
it matured, | could not perceive any difference in
the quantity of cheat, there appeared to be as much
with that produced from the seed had been so care
full to separate the cheat FROM as in that from other
seed am, therefore, Of opinion, that from some
cause unknown, wheat does turn to cheat A. p
AGREClJE., FUR AT,

ON Wheat TURNING TO CHEAT.


South-Carolina, August &c, 1927

Be very careful TO gather all punctured or decay
ed fruit whether your trees or on the ground and
give them to your hogs, If you do not, the worms
which they contain, and which have been the cause
of their premature decay, will make their escape
into the ground, and you will find the evils which
await their visitatons will increase upon you another
season.
FALLEN FRUIT.

There are thousands if not tens of thousands Of
bushels of wild grapes of various kinds, now grow
ing in the different sections Of our country. each
bushe of which will make from two to three gal
Ions of vine; much better than the wretched stuff
imported in wood called Caret and other '.rot gut'
imported Wiaes Of low prices.


had some Fox grapes gathered for experiment.
from Where they grow naturally; after bruisng them
and straning them through thin piece of muslin.
tried specific gravity. and found it to be 1865,
Which was the average of three different wines, and
which is equal one pound four ounces Of the sweet
principles that is[sugar to gallon Of the juice or
must.
FRIDAY, .H'0reusber 8, 1927

The law and the facts which relate to the execu-


on of the six militiamen by order OF Gen, Jackson,
after their term Of service had expired, appear to
be imperfectly understood by some, and those who
are employed to whitewash Gen. jackson have
taken advantage Of this effectiveness Of knowledge
to involve the public mind in deeper mist Of err
on this subject. 1t is time that those outrages
on TRUTH and those abuses of public confidence, on
the part of those who rely Justification and mys
terry for the attainment of their ends, should be met
and corrected and that the people should be put
in possession of simple and accurate statement Of
the whole Affair."


For the purpose of producing clear conception
of the subject, we first of all quote the charge ITSELF
as it is given in the report of the Nashville Commit
tee, dated April 25, 1927. He is charged with
having caused the execution of six mtiamen, Tor
crimes committed after their term of service had
expired.''


The conviction of the men for g ssmutiny'' and
'' connivng at mutiny,'' by court martial compos-
ed of three regular members and two .upernumera-
ries, and their execution established by extracts
certified by Andrew J. Donnelson, /" copied from
the original proceedings of the Court which he
had received from Col. Robert Butler. late Adju-
tant General OF the Southern Division" and by the
order issued by command of Gen. Jackson on the
22d of January 1915, for the execution, four days
after its promu CATION at Mobile. Of those proceed
ings there trace the records of the War De-
partment, (the only document filed there being the
general order above referred to,) although the fol-
lowing clause in the Articles of War expressly pro-
vdes that proceedings of courts martial shall be trans
mtted to the Department for preservation
art 80. Every judge Advocate or person Off
ciatng as such at any general court martial shall
transmit, with as much expedition the opportunl-
ty Of time and distance of place admit, the orr
sinal proceedings and sentence of such court mar
tial, to the Secretary of War, which said original
proceedings and sentence shall be carefully kept
and preserved in the office Of said Secretary to the
end that the persons entitled thereto may me ena-
bled, upon application 10 the said office, to obtain
copies thereof"


| Instead Of being thus transmitted, we find the
proceedings in the hands Of Une Of the family Of
General Jackson, circumstance which at once
proves the violation of the Article of War, and war;
rants the inference that such violation was risked to


reserve the character OF General Jackson from the
effect of any future investigation.


The cruelty Of the act could only be met by pal


atlves, aud those have been pentitully, but very
unsuccesstully, administered by the editors of the
General but the Megaluy of it mas been encoun-
tered by direct denial. The editor of the rele-
graph at once hazarded the declaration that the
i Tennessee militia were mustered into service for
six months.'' In reply to this the Democratic
Press refers the editor Of the Telegraph to the War
Department for evidence that Gov. Blount made
application to Mr.. Madison that the term of the mi
litia service 'sshould not exceed three months.',
; sc. and that Mr.. Madison s'drected that they
: should serve only that time" The Democratic
: Press has committed an error in making this cor-
respondence between Gov. Blount and MIR. Maa-
son refer to the militia whose term of service expir
ed on the 10Th OF September. 1914. 1t had refer
ence to given period In order to test the legai-
, ty OF the act, we proceed to statement of the
vera laws relating to the militia when called into
service.


: The law which provides for calling forth the
b,ab I,n.,


date Feb %, 1895, and the 4th section of this law
5 declares


3 That no officer, on.commissoned officer, or
, private, of the militia, shall be compelled to serve


more than three months after his arrival at the place


OF rendezvous, in any one year, nor more than in


due rotation with every other able bodied man of the
same rank in the battalion to which he belongs.'
: A law, temporary in its operation, and enacted
for special purpose, was passed on the 10th Of
April, 1912, authorizing ''a detachment from the
militia of the United States.'' This law authoriz-
ed requistion upon the governors of the several
States, for their respective proportions of hun


dred thousand militia. officers included. The third
D section of this act, which has been quoted by the
editor of the Telegraph as the guide of the conduct
of Gen. Jackson in Jan. 1915, runs thus
"And be it further enacted, that the said detach-


ment shall not be compelled to serve longer time


than six months after they arrive at the place Of


rendezvous"


The ninth section of the same act runs thus


Sec. 9. And be it further enacted, that this act
shall continue and be in force for the term of too


gears from The passing thereof and no onger''


The act consequently expired according to its
own limitation the 10th of April, 1914. 1t was
never re-enacted, nor was provision similar to
that contained in the third section, and relied on by
the Telegraph to establish the legality of Gen.
Jackson's conduct, included in any subsequent law


From the 10th to the 18th Of April, ,sl4. there

AS the common Fox grape and other large grapes
are now ripe and other wild grapes will be ripen-
ing in succession until after frost, wish to draw
the attention Of our farmers and others to this OBJ
iect am led to do this, as there is not one per-
son in one hundred thousand that knows or has any
idea of the advantages we possess at the present
moment,

TO the Editor Of The Georgetoacn Colombian, and


District advertiser.

imported ,oi1aes Of loao prices


had some Fox grapes gathered for experiment,
from Where they grow naturally; after bruslng them
and strainlng them through thin piece of muslin.
tried specific gravity. and found it to be 1865,
winch was the average of three different wines, and
which is equal TO one pound four Of the sweet
principles that isl sugar. to gallon Of the juice or
must.


TO make Time Of V7ld Grapes.


Gather the grapes when ripe and bruise them with
mae, or in any other way. just to crack the skin
is sufficient, but take care n0t to bruise the seeds
and when the grapes are bruised, put them into an
open headed cask Or tub but do not fill more than
two-thlrds full, where they to remain from one,
to two or three days, according to the temperature
of the weather. until the pu por colouring matter,
is dissolved. The skins and seeds will have risen
to the surface and the wine is to be drawn off by
hole made within one or two inches of the bottom:
the wine will run of oerably clear, but have hair
sieve to let it run through to catch any thing that
may run off with the wine-and when you have the
Wine drawn Oft, add sugar to your taste. or it is
better way to add sugar until fresh egg swims, just
50 tiiat the upper edge is with the surface Of
the must; and it is dissolved. put it into
clean cask well fumigated with sup pher match
and bung it up tight; bore small gimbe hole near
the bung. into which puta peg, not tight but lit
tie air may escape to keep the cask from bursting
In about three weeks, drive the peg in tight and it
is not necessary to look at it again until the first
week in December. when in nine casks out of ten,
the wine will be perfectly fine and bright; you need
not be under any apprehension about fermentation,
as II, viii 81 on its own way, and nature will per-
form her office in the best manner possible
| On clear cold day early in December examine
your wine, and in nine cases out of ten it will br
completely fermented, and it will be perfectly fiue
and bright. Then rack it off into clean cask, fu-
mgated with sulpher match, and in the month Of
| March, following, rack it again as above-and if it
should not be perfectly fine, fine it with [ifred wine
the whites of eggs--if white wine, with milk


1t all these operations done with proper careit
will then be ncorruptble and last for an age or ages
if necessary.


am here speaking of the Fox and other larger
grapes.


If the smaller grapes used, such as the fall or


frost grapes or others, the chicken pigeon which
are full OF seeds and have thick calnmy iuice it
will be necessary to add from one gallon to gallon
and half Of water to the bushel of grapes, either
before or after they are bruised, the grapes to be
hrst measured III the clusterput the water to them
IA little more than milk warm, and rub them well
with the hand, then put them into cask or tub as
above mentioned, and follow the directions given for
the manufacture Of the Fox grape wine. In rub.
bng them with your hands, it is very easy to get
most of the stems off the grapes, and if separated,
will make neater wine.


Where you have not the means of getting the in
struments for asceraining the specific gravity of the
must OF the grape, and you wish wine to keep foI
an indefinite length of time. the way is to add sugar
to the must slowly, and dissolve it until fresh land
ess swlms. so that the upper edge is just even with
the surface OF the mast of the grapes, which viii


then be equal to about three pounds of the sweet
principle, sugar: to the gallon; where there are
but two pounds OF the sweet principle in the gallon


a f3J fnh ha ri anG .,ifh IL,
the twelvemonth following But for your grog btus
ers, whisky, rum. and Madeira drinkers, who drink
torthe Intoxicating quality and ao for Mefauoy'-
1t will be necessary to add from three to four gallons
of brandy to the barrel of wine.-With four gallons
of brandy to the bae that wine which has but twt
pounds of the sweet principle to the gallon, will
suit most vitlated tastes best.


, There is now sufficient quantity of the wilt
chicken and frost grapes within half a mile of m,
/ home to make pipe of wine, and l should suppose
thatin Non gomery county, which joins the Distric
OF Colombia, there are wild grapes sufficient, if thev
E were all gathered, to make between one and 2O(


pipes, otherwise they will be left to fall and rot OF


the ground, or be eaten by the birds-and in th,


whole state of Maryland, there is now at this pres
ent moment, enough of wild grapes on the vines t,
! make two thousand pipes of wine, and many of thu
other states would produce as much: which woul.
be WORTH if properly manufactured, from fifty t,
> one hundred cents the gallon.


JOHN ADI,UM.
r September "a, 1897.


P.S. have always observed that the wild grapes
! are infinitely more abundant in slatey, graveIly,
sandy and other poor land than on the rich lime
stone lands.

full articles.headline: PRESERVATION OF CABBAGEs.
full articles.article:
The London Monthly Magazine gives the follow
ing method by which the Portuguese preserve cab
bage on board their ships. The cabbage is cut SO
as to leave about two inches or of the stem at
tached toit; after which the ph is scooped out to
to about the depth Of in-h, peing taken not
wound or bruise the rnd by this operation. The
cabbages then are suspended by means of a cord,
tied round that portion OF the stem next the cabbage,
and fastened at regular intervals to rope across
the decks. That portion of the stem from which
the pith is taken being uppermost, is regularly fill
ed with water during very long voyages. The same
method might be advantageously adopted in private
houses.

FrociaIn the bounties that can never fail

speak or Thy majesty in words of flame;

Each on its own firm pole,

That sacred spot would seek,

full articles.headline:
AGREClJE., FUR AT,

ON Wheat TURNING TO CHEAT.


South-Carolina, August &c, 1927
full articles.article:
South-Carolina, August &c, 1897.
Mr.. SKINNER,


SIR Having seen in your paper, No l5, some
remarks by farmer OF Frederick county, Va. reia-
tive to cheat in wheat; and giving his opinion thai
wheat does not turn to cheat, have thought proper
to offer you an experimental fact, and if you think
It merits place in your useful paper, you can give
It one. In the year 1928. my crop of wheat had in
it considerable quantity of cheat which was at
loss to account for. had seen none the preceding
year; but in order to clear my wheat from cheat
entirely, as thought, selected from the best part
Of my crop some of the best bundles, and carefully
separated all the cheat from The wheat before it was
threshed this work was not entrusted to servants,
or 10 any other person but tmysef; was, therefore,
perfectly satisfied that no cheat was left with the
wheat; this wheat was seeded separate from any
other; but when it became of such size as to dis
tnguish it from the cheat and from that time until
it matured, | could not perceive any difference in
the quantity of cheat, there appeared to be as much
with that produced from the seed had been so care
full to separate the cheat FROM as in that from other
seed am, therefore, Of opinion, that from some
cause unknown, wheat does turn to cheat A. p

full articles.headline: FALLEN FRUIT.
full articles.article:
Be very careful TO gather all punctured or decay
ed fruit whether your trees or on the ground and
give them to your hogs, If you do not, the worms
which they contain, and which have been the cause
of their premature decay, will make their escape
into the ground, and you will find the evils which
await their visitatons will increase upon you another
season.

which is equal one pound four ounces Of the sweet

must.

reserve the character OF General Jackson from the
effect of any future investigation.


The cruelty Of the act could only be met by pal


atlves, aud those have been pentitully, but very
unsuccesstully, administered by the editors of the
General but the Megaluy of it mas been encoun-
tered by direct denial. The editor of the rele-
graph at once hazarded the declaration that the
i Tennessee militia were mustered into service for
six months.'' In reply to this the Democratic
Press refers the editor Of the Telegraph to the War
Department for evidence that Gov. Blount made
application to Mr.. Madison that the term of the mi
litia service 'sshould not exceed three months.',
; sc. and that Mr.. Madison s'drected that they
: should serve only that time" The Democratic
: Press has committed an error in making this cor-
respondence between Gov. Blount and MIR. Maa-
son refer to the militia whose term of service expir
ed on the 10Th OF September. 1914. 1t had refer
ence to given period In order to test the legai-
, ty OF the act, we proceed to statement of the
vera laws relating to the militia when called into
service.


: The law which provides for calling forth the
b,ab I,n.,


date Feb %, 1895, and the 4th section of this law
5 declares


3 That no officer, on.commissoned officer, or
, private, of the militia, shall be compelled to serve


more than three months after his arrival at the place


OF rendezvous, in any one year, nor more than in


due rotation with every other able bodied man of the
same rank in the battalion to which he belongs.'
: A law, temporary in its operation, and enacted
for special purpose, was passed on the 10th Of
April, 1912, authorizing ''a detachment from the
militia of the United States.'' This law authoriz-
ed requistion upon the governors of the several
States, for their respective proportions of hun


dred thousand militia. officers included. The third
D section of this act, which has been quoted by the
editor of the Telegraph as the guide of the conduct
of Gen. Jackson in Jan. 1915, runs thus
"And be it further enacted, that the said detach-


ment shall not be compelled to serve longer time


than six months after they arrive at the place Of


rendezvous"


The ninth section of the same act runs thus


Sec. 9. And be it further enacted, that this act
shall continue and be in force for the term of too


gears from The passing thereof and no onger''


The act consequently expired according to its
own limitation the 10th of April, 1914. 1t was
never re-enacted, nor was provision similar to
that contained in the third section, and relied on by
the Telegraph to establish the legality of Gen.
Jackson's conduct, included in any subsequent law


From the 10th to the 18th Of April, ,sl4. there

full articles.headline:
TO the Editor Of The Georgetoacn Colombian, and


District advertiser.
full articles.article:
AS the common Fox grape and other large grapes
are now ripe and other wild grapes will be ripen-
ing in succession until after frost, wish to draw
the attention Of our farmers and others to this OBJ
iect am led to do this, as there is not one per-
son in one hundred thousand that knows or has any
idea of the advantages we possess at the present
moment,

imported ,oi1aes Of loao prices


had some Fox grapes gathered for experiment,
from Where they grow naturally; after bruslng them
and strainlng them through thin piece of muslin.
tried specific gravity. and found it to be 1865,
winch was the average of three different wines, and
which is equal TO one pound four Of the sweet
principles that isl sugar. to gallon Of the juice or
must.


TO make Time Of V7ld Grapes.


Gather the grapes when ripe and bruise them with
mae, or in any other way. just to crack the skin
is sufficient, but take care n0t to bruise the seeds
and when the grapes are bruised, put them into an
open headed cask Or tub but do not fill more than
two-thlrds full, where they to remain from one,
to two or three days, according to the temperature
of the weather. until the pu por colouring matter,
is dissolved. The skins and seeds will have risen
to the surface and the wine is to be drawn off by
hole made within one or two inches of the bottom:
the wine will run of oerably clear, but have hair
sieve to let it run through to catch any thing that
may run off with the wine-and when you have the
Wine drawn Oft, add sugar to your taste. or it is
better way to add sugar until fresh egg swims, just
50 tiiat the upper edge is with the surface Of
the must; and it is dissolved. put it into
clean cask well fumigated with sup pher match
and bung it up tight; bore small gimbe hole near
the bung. into which puta peg, not tight but lit
tie air may escape to keep the cask from bursting
In about three weeks, drive the peg in tight and it
is not necessary to look at it again until the first
week in December. when in nine casks out of ten,
the wine will be perfectly fine and bright; you need
not be under any apprehension about fermentation,
as II, viii 81 on its own way, and nature will per-
form her office in the best manner possible
| On clear cold day early in December examine
your wine, and in nine cases out of ten it will br
completely fermented, and it will be perfectly fiue
and bright. Then rack it off into clean cask, fu-
mgated with sulpher match, and in the month Of
| March, following, rack it again as above-and if it
should not be perfectly fine, fine it with [ifred wine
the whites of eggs--if white wine, with milk


1t all these operations done with proper careit
will then be ncorruptble and last for an age or ages
if necessary.


am here speaking of the Fox and other larger
grapes.


If the smaller grapes used, such as the fall or


frost grapes or others, the chicken pigeon which
are full OF seeds and have thick calnmy iuice it
will be necessary to add from one gallon to gallon
and half Of water to the bushel of grapes, either
before or after they are bruised, the grapes to be
hrst measured III the clusterput the water to them
IA little more than milk warm, and rub them well
with the hand, then put them into cask or tub as
above mentioned, and follow the directions given for
the manufacture Of the Fox grape wine. In rub.
bng them with your hands, it is very easy to get
most of the stems off the grapes, and if separated,
will make neater wine.


Where you have not the means of getting the in
struments for asceraining the specific gravity of the
must OF the grape, and you wish wine to keep foI
an indefinite length of time. the way is to add sugar
to the must slowly, and dissolve it until fresh land
ess swlms. so that the upper edge is just even with
the surface OF the mast of the grapes, which viii


then be equal to about three pounds of the sweet
principle, sugar: to the gallon; where there are
but two pounds OF the sweet principle in the gallon


a f3J fnh ha ri anG .,ifh IL,
the twelvemonth following But for your grog btus
ers, whisky, rum. and Madeira drinkers, who drink
torthe Intoxicating quality and ao for Mefauoy'-
1t will be necessary to add from three to four gallons
of brandy to the barrel of wine.-With four gallons
of brandy to the bae that wine which has but twt
pounds of the sweet principle to the gallon, will
suit most vitlated tastes best.


, There is now sufficient quantity of the wilt
chicken and frost grapes within half a mile of m,
/ home to make pipe of wine, and l should suppose
thatin Non gomery county, which joins the Distric
OF Colombia, there are wild grapes sufficient, if thev
E were all gathered, to make between one and 2O(


pipes, otherwise they will be left to fall and rot OF


the ground, or be eaten by the birds-and in th,


whole state of Maryland, there is now at this pres
ent moment, enough of wild grapes on the vines t,
! make two thousand pipes of wine, and many of thu
other states would produce as much: which woul.
be WORTH if properly manufactured, from fifty t,
> one hundred cents the gallon.


JOHN ADI,UM.
r September "a, 1897.


P.S. have always observed that the wild grapes
! are infinitely more abundant in slatey, graveIly,
sandy and other poor land than on the rich lime
stone lands.
